Eco is easily one of the most thoughtful and engaging community-driven games I’ve ever played. It’s a rare title that blends crafting, politics, economy, environment, and cooperation into a single living world where every decision matters. The sense of progression—both personal and communal—is incredibly rewarding. From the first laws you write to the first roads you build, every moment feels like you’re contributing to something larger than yourself.

The game absolutely shines in its early and mid-game. There’s nothing quite like the harmony of players discovering roles, forming governments, setting tax laws, debating policies, and shaping the world with purpose. When a server is active, Eco becomes a thriving little civilization, full of personality, culture, and community storytelling. It’s the kind of multiplayer experience that sticks with you long after you log out.

That said, I have one big wish for Eco’s future:
Once industry is unlocked, the momentum on most servers drops dramatically. After about a week—when the majority of techs are researched and people have built their factories—servers tend to empty as players jump into a fresh start rather than continue world-building or developing culture. It’s understandable, but also a missed opportunity, because Eco has so much potential for long-lasting civilizations.

I would love to hear more from the developers about their long-term vision for keeping players engaged after industry begins. Whether that means deeper cultural systems, expanded late-game goals, meaningful long-lasting projects, or evolving world events—Eco is so close to being not just a game about building a society, but sustaining one.

In short: Eco is fantastic, unique, and absolutely worth playing. I just hope future updates find a way to keep servers alive and thriving deep into the late game—because the foundation they’ve built is too good not to carry further.

Eco’s one of those games that really gets under your skin in a good way. It’s got depth for days - farming, trading, grinding, setting up markets - it all ties together nicely. Nothing feels wasted. You put the work in and you see it pay off, whether that’s in your crops, the economy, or the way the community starts to function. The visuals are easy on the eyes too, clean and colourful without being over the top.

What makes it special though is the community side. Jumping on a server, working with other players, trading and building a proper little world - it just feels right. It’s not just another survival game where you bash trees and call it a day; it’s about building something bigger with other people.

Now, for the gripes. Alt accounts are a killer. With the small player base the game already has, seeing the market undercut by alts is rough. And don’t get me started on the preset governments—they suck the life out of what should be the most interesting part of the game. Instead of letting things grow naturally and watching politics evolve, you’re boxed into some cookie-cutter setup. Takes the spark out of it.

All up, Eco is a bloody good time if you’re into community-driven games and don’t mind a bit of grind. When it clicks, it’s brilliant. It’s one of my favourites.

My best advice is to find a good long-term server with a group that has demonstrated their willingness to play to the end.

You will encounter bugs, unbalanced gameplay, and the updates (when they do come) may not always be what you wanted. For example, the game recently implemented dinner parties in v12. While this is a cool, community-building feature, there are so many other things that I would rather see the devs working on instead like the much-publicized skill star-rework or animal husbandry. Eco isn’t just another survival crafting game — it’s a living, breathing simulation of how civilization and the environment intertwine. Every tree you cut, every road you build, every law you pass has real consequences for the ecosystem and economy. It challenges players to think collectively, balancing progress with sustainability in a shared online world.
